unnormalised: Planning a trip in India? Budgeting can be tricky, especially when you're trying to figure out how much ₹ you'll need. Let's break down the common expenses so you can prepone your dream vacay with less stress. Accommodation is a big one. You'll find everything from backpacker hostels at ₹500 per night to luxury hotels costing upwards of Rs. 15000. It really depends on your travel style and how much you're willing to spend.
normalised: Planning a trip in India? Budgeting can be tricky, especially when you're trying to figure out how much rupee you'll need. Let's break down the common expenses so you can prepone your dream vacay with less stress. Accommodation is a big one. You'll find everything from backpacker hostels at rupee five hundred per night to luxury hotels costing upwards of rupees fifteen thousand. It really depends on your travel style and how much you're willing to spend.

unnormalised: Next up, transport. Internal flights can range from Rs. 2500 to Rs. 8000, depending on the distance and the airline. Trains are a more budget-friendly option, with sleeper class tickets costing as little as ₹300 for overnight journeys. Auto-rickshaws and taxis are readily available in cities, but negotiate the fare beforehand! Expect to pay around Rs. 50 per km in most cities. Also keep in mind metro costs, usually around Rs. 10-60.
normalised: Next up, transport. Internal flights can range from rupees two thousand five hundred to rupees eight thousand, depending on the distance and the airline. Trains are a more budget-friendly option, with sleeper class tickets costing as little as rupee three hundred for overnight journeys. Auto-rickshaws and taxis are readily available in cities, but negotiate the fare beforehand! Expect to pay around rupees fifty per kilometer in most cities. Also keep in mind metro costs, usually around rupees ten to sixty.

unnormalised: Food is where India shines! Street food is incredibly affordable and delicious, with a plate of momos costing just Rs. 50. A decent restaurant meal will set you back around ₹300-₹700 per person. Budget about Rs. 50-100 for chai and snacks throughout the day - you won't regret it! Remember to factor in the cost of bottled water, which is usually around Rs. 20 per bottle, especially if you're sensitive to water quality.

Remember to factor in the cost of bottled water, which is usually around rupees twenty per bottle, especially if you're sensitive to water quality.

unnormalised: Sightseeing is another important expense. Entry fees to monuments and museums vary, but generally range from Rs. 25 for Indians to Rs. 500 for foreigners. Don't forget about activities like boat rides or guided tours, which can cost anywhere from Rs. 100 to Rs. 1500 per activity. If you plan on visiting a lot of historical sites, a combined entry ticket might be a good idea, and can often be booked online for convenience.

If you plan on visiting a lot of historical sites, a combined entry ticket might be a good idea, and can often be booked online for convenience.

unnormalised: Souvenirs are tempting, but they can quickly add up! Set a budget of, say, Rs. 1000 for small trinkets and handicrafts. Remember to bargain respectfully, especially in local markets. Credit cards are accepted in many places, but it's always a good idea to carry cash, particularly in smaller towns and villages. Keep a watchful eye on your belongings, especially in crowded areas.

unnormalised: Lastly, factor in miscellaneous expenses. SIM cards are cheap and easy to obtain, costing around ₹100, plus the cost of data packs. Tips for drivers, waiters, and hotel staff are customary, though not mandatory (usually 5-10%). It’s wise to have some reserve money as well (e.g. Rs. 5000) in case of unexpected events or delays.

unnormalised: So, to summarise? A budget traveller can easily get by on ₹1500-₹2500 per day. A mid-range traveller should plan on spending Rs. 3000-Rs. 5000 per day. And a luxury traveller? The sky’s the limit! With a little planning, you can enjoy an incredible trip to India without breaking the bank. Enjoy your travels!
